title: The Art of Tết Preparation

photographer.name: Example Photographer
photographer.bio: Documentary photographer specializing in Vietnamese cultural traditions

coverImage.alt: Elderly woman preparing traditional bánh chưng for Tết celebration
coverImage.caption: Three generations gather to prepare traditional Tết foods

summary: Three generations of women gather in a rural village to prepare traditional foods for Vietnamese New Year, maintaining customs passed down through centuries of celebration.

story.introduction: As the lunar new year approaches, families across Vietnam gather to honor ancient traditions. In the Mekong Delta, we witness the timeless ritual of Tết preparation.

body.content: The preparation begins days before the actual celebration. In rural Vietnamese villages, the making of bánh chưng remains a sacred family tradition, bringing together multiple generations in a labor of love that has remained unchanged for centuries.

body.alt: Hands wrapping sticky rice in banana leaves
body.caption: The careful wrapping of glutinous rice and mung bean filling in banana leaves requires skill passed down through generations

body.content: Bà Năm, 72, learned this art from her grandmother. Now, she teaches her daughter and granddaughters the precise technique required to create the perfect square cake that symbolizes the earth in Vietnamese cosmology.
When we make bánh chưng together, we're not just preparing food. We're keeping our ancestors' spirits alive, sharing their wisdom with the next generation.

body.alt: Three generations of women preparing Tết foods together
body.caption: Grandmother, mother, and daughter work in harmony, each contributing their knowledge and skills

body.content: The youngest member of the family, 8-year-old Linh, watches intently as her grandmother's weathered hands expertly fold the banana leaves. Through observation and practice, she becomes part of an unbroken chain connecting past, present, and future.

story.conclusion: As the cakes simmer overnight, filling the house with their distinctive aroma, these women have done more than prepare for Tết—they've woven another thread in the tapestry of Vietnamese cultural continuity.
